Um, I haven’t quite made up my mind on this issue yet. So, I can’t definitively say whether either side is right or wrong. But, I do believe this is one of the trickiest topics we’re dealing with today. It’s so close to the line between church and state, and figuring out how to define marriage without offending anyone is a real challenge. I don’t know, I think civil unions should just be recognized as a civil union, and not something the government should intervene with, for fear of offending religious sensibilities. After all, if people are married, they should be looked at as any other couple in a civil union. The whole idea of defining marriage is quite tricky, especially when it comes to something like same-sex marriage. If all states can come to a logical conclusion about it, then I think they should push for it to become federal law. However, amending the constitution to ban same-sex marriage seems ridiculous. It’s just not important enough to amend the constitution for such a cause. Simply put, no.

I grew up in a Christian household, so the topic of homosexuality is a bit of a gray area for me. I have many gay friends, and I don't necessarily agree with their lifestyle, but I believe it should be legalized. I don't think it should be a national issue, but rather something each state should decide on its own. Many states are democratic, and they will likely push for gay marriage. If you're living in a democratic state, you should respect the decision of that state, as you've chosen to live there. Therefore, I believe homosexuals should have the same opportunities as heterosexuals and that each state should decide whether to legalize gay marriage on their own. I don't think President Bush should impose a national ban on gay marriage; it should be up to each individual state. I just don't think he can decide for the entire country, as he doesn't live in every state. Plus, he'll be out of office soon. A change in the presidency might just bring about a different policy. So, it should be up to each individual state, as they are the ones who will have to live with the decision.

Some people are under the impression that they can share personal information on the internet without consequence. But let's break this down. A social networking site like Myspace, by definition, is intended for public viewing. If you post something on the web, you're doing so with the understanding that others, including school officials, can see it. Whether it's under the school's name or not, they can access it through their homes. Now, I'm not saying that school officials should use the internet to snoop on students. That's an invasion of privacy. But if the information they find could prevent a school shooting or make the school a safer place, then I believe they have every right to monitor it. After all, parents expect their children to be in a safe environment when they're dropped off at school. And the school system has a responsibility to ensure that. We practice lock downs and drills to prepare for emergencies, including school shootings. So, if school officials find information that could help prevent such tragedies, it's not an invasion of privacy; it's them doing their job to keep students safe.

I was initially all for the war. I was deeply affected by 9/11 and wanted to strike back. However, in hindsight, I think we overlooked many factors and rushed into the conflict without a clear plan. I now believe that it backfired on us. Initially, I was all for it, but my perspective has since shifted. I don't think our presence in the region is making any difference. They are too busy fighting amongst themselves to fight against us. I think we should just leave. I don't think we were prepared for what we found there, and the concept of war is different for them than it is for us. They don't seem interested in improving their country, only in getting us to leave. I think we were more driven by emotion than logic. We went in seeking revenge, and President Bush acted based on public sentiment. We had to declare war, but we could have done so with a better plan. I don't think we made enough progress to warrant staying. The longer we stay, the more it seems like it will collapse once we leave. I think we're only hurting ourselves by staying. I don't think we can change those people, and it's time to admit that our efforts haven't been successful.
